title: Between 25 October and 31 December 2017, will North Korea launch an SLBM?
preds: Kim is unpredictably dangerous but this possibility seems unlikely.

I have no knowledge about their submarines, but if advances have been made, he will certainly test launch. The inly thing he can't do is put a nuclear bomb on it or a guidance system that will show it what direction to fly. No sattelites in space. Anyway too late this year.

Comments: Barges as launch platforms for testing appear more viable at this time.
The Washington Post, December 27, 'Documents shed light on North Korea’s startling gains in sea-based missile technology': https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/documents-shed-light-on-north-koreas-startling-gains-in-sea-based-missile-technology/2017/12/27/dd82878a-e749-11e7-ab50-621fe0588340_story.html?utm_term=.4ab124da02cc
Clips from article:
"On June 22, 2016, North Korea successfully tested a mysterious new missile that differed dramatically from anything in Pyongyang’s known arsenal. The 36-foot-tall missile had a squat, snub-nosed frame and used a liquid propellent more powerful than the kerosene-based fuels the North Koreans had used in the past, potentially allowing it to fly farther, with heavier payloads.
The missile was dubbed the Hwasong-10, or Musudan. But experts noted striking similarities to the R-27 Zyb, or Ripple, manufactured by the Makeyev Rocket Design Bureau. Two months later, on Aug. 24, 2016, North Korea successfully tested the Pukguksong-1, a submarine-launched missile that also incorporates some features from the Zyb. Both models are “generally regarded as derived from the designs of the Makeyev Bureau’s R-27,” said Joshua Pollack, an analyst at the James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies in Monterey, Calif.
Those two tests were followed in recent months by even greater technological leaps, culminating in the successful tests this year of North Korea’s first true intercontinental ballistic missiles, capable of reaching every city in the continental United States. There have been no further tests of the Musudan, but satellite images released this month show that North Korea is building floating barges thought to be intended for tests of new submarine-launched missiles. The construction is occurring in two different ports on opposite sides of the country.
U.S. analysts also believe that North Korea is working on an improved version of the Pukguksong."

There were several SLBM tests made in the last 24 months, and there is still a issue of the missile clearing the tube (sub) before the main engine lights. Imagery in November shows a second barge being readied for testing. Hence it is unlikely they would launch from a sub that could be disastrous instead of more tests from an already bought-and-paid-for test barge. As there is only a few days left in the year, the odds of a cold weather launch is extraordinarily low. I'm annoyed that I can enter 0.5%

Relatively infrequent launches. Successful SLBM in August 2016. Most recent (Pukkuksong-2) launch was land based.

Seems like the last actual SLBM (from a submarine) was in 2016. The recently launched ICBM was liquid fueled and was launched on Nov 29. Seems like from a technology standpoint, an SLBM would be a good next display and queued up for another test (solid state, actual submarine launch). However, these "tests" are also strategically done from a communications standpoint. With the last successful test Nov29th I think NK will ride that wave for a bit. There is also no big Asian to US politics stuff for December so I give this a very low possibility.

See http://www.38north.org/2017/12/nampo120117/
"Commercial satellite imagery from November 11, 16 and 24 show that North Korea’s second submersible ballistic missile test stand barge—a platform that allows for underwater missile launches outside of submarines—located at the Nampo Navy Shipyard is being prepared to enter service, a strong indicator that Pyongyang is advancing its submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) program.[1] During this time, the barge was moved from the construction way and berthed alongside the nearby fitting-out dock. This is where vessels are positioned when their hulls are sound yet require systems (e.g., pumps, electrical, communications, etc.) to be installed, modified or repaired, or to have minor work completed on their superstructures before becoming operational. Once in service, this barge will help facilitate a broader SLBM "

What would be the next step for NK after today's missile launch?  They have perfected a submerged launch system.  They have perfected their missiles.  They have a submarine that can carry the missiles.  They've demonstrated that they have the technology and the will to continue testing.  The ongoing trend is to demonstrate continuing progress and to escalate.  I think they will eventually, but sometime in the next thirty days after today's launch is a very short time.  I'd place odds lower, somewhere just under a 1/5 chance.

Dateline 11-15-2017 Rest and refit. North Korea hasn’t fired a missile in two months, but that’s in keeping with its normal seasonal testing schedule, Bloomberg points out. The Korean People’s Army regularly enters its training cycle every winter “and getting ready for it involves a calm before the storm,” said Van Jackson, a strategy fellow at the Center for Strategic Studies at Victoria University of Wellington. -- Situation Report, presented by  ... Foreign Policy [fp@foreignpolicy.com]

Prior to North Korea’s second ICBM test in July, U.S. intelligence had assessed that a new SLBM flight test was likely. This assessment was revised downward in August following North Korea’s second ICBM test in late-July. As of early October, an SLBM flight test was not seen as imminent by U.S. intelligence.

I think there is a misconception regarding the number of North Korean SLBM tests that have occurred in the past.  This is partially because they have been testing SLBM missiles from land sites and have only recently transitioned to sea based launches.  Instead of counting the number of SLBM launches, we should be analyzing the total number of tests of the Pukkuksong, which is North Korea's main SLBM.

The intelligence record at predicting DPRK weapons tests is very poor beyond a timeframe of a few days. I count three successful tests meeting the criteria in the last two years, and factoring in North Korea's tendency to INCREASE its belligerence during high tension, I tend towards a higher-than-average figure here.

Less than even odds, but is a two month window for this question, giving some time for the North Koreans to work up towards a test. With a new submarine under construction, new tests will occur at some point.

A chance exists for the North Korean regime to reciprocate rising tensions between it and the United States. However, despite the rhetoric taking place, Kim Jong-un is a rational actor seeking stability of his regime. Under the current international context, he recognizes the capability that a SLBM launch signals, combined with progress in nuclear testing. Kim Jong-un appreciates that this action could escalate tensions beyond his desired level (i.e. U.S. strike or intervention). He would likely keep this option close hold under his escalation of force continuum as a response to an increased level, or capability, in U.S. military demonstrations beyond historical norms. Kim Jong-un would most likely not initiate this test unilaterally absent a political objective to tie it to - matching U.S. military deterrence actions.

Forecast based on expectation that NK will conduct further sea based ejector system tests before a live launch.  2016 SLBM launch was though to have a max. Range of approx. 600 miles, next lauch would possibly test a more advanced system.
This is my initial forecast.  The last test was in August of 2016.  New reports suggest a SLBM is not an imminent threat by US Intelligence.  Low chance.

Data exist which indicate, via a atellite imagery, that there has been recent work on barge 2 at the site where the only submarine that NK owns for SLBMs;  imagery indicate the the barge has been upended, which makes assessment of what is occurring more difficult.   Analysts indicate that the western coast of NK, where a launch of SLBMs would occur, that the following factors be investigated more thoroughly:   there is no way to determine via satellite imaging whether the barge is being worked for future testing:  that work on  the SLBMs are being produced at a faster rate than events prior to September 2017; several factors of which are likely but not mutually exclusive (a property of joint sets in operations. This  indicates that closer examination of what is occurring on the west coast of NK should shoulde be made and a higher priority placed on SLMBs development, component testing, and a final testing phase to determine whether components and other mechanisms are functional and successful at launch.

Haven't fired an SLBM since February, failed test would hamper their newly-acquired veneer of ballistic missile competence & give less leverage on world stage. Would be lower but several DPRK festivals (including their Constitution Day) are in late December.
The near term focus will be on hydrogen bomb tests and ICBM testing.  The SLBM program will be the most secretive and likely not until 2018.

NK launched a sub into international waters. They are also in the process of constructing a new (larger) submarine. The two coinciding indicates a desire to test a farther range SLBM. It has also been a year since the last SLBM test, they are due for a show of power. Especially since japans sitting government further solidified their position.

Usually there are more than one tests in a year; in 2017 there has been only one. And earlier there have been fully or partially successful tests conducted from submarines (instead of a barge), so a submarine test is likely (or at least possible). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pukkuksong-1 However, the given time frame is rather short and "the current imagery does not indicate an imminent test" (http://www.38north.org/2017/10/sinpo101117/).
Flurry of news reports in August. Nothing recently.
Typically the North tests SLBMs several times a year and they have only tested once this year. Given their historical rate of testing I expect to see at least one more this year.

Comment: Still see them working out the kinks.
The Diplomat, October 24, 'North Korea Has Tested a New Solid-Fuel Missile Engine - North Korean scientists tested a new solid fuel engine on October 2017. What system is it destined for?': https://thediplomat.com/2017/10/north-korea-has-tested-a-new-solid-fuel-missile-engine/
Clips from above Diplomat article:
"The test is the first reported static solid-fuel test since March 2016, when North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong-un inspected the test of what North Korean state media described as a “high-powered solid-fuel rocket engine and stage separation.” The engine was tested in a horizontal configuration unlike North Korea’s vertically configured tests of large liquid-fuel ballistic missile engines.
In September 2017, Japan’s Asahi Shimbun had reported a failed test of a new solid-fuel engine for a submarine-launched ballistic missile at Sinpo, but The Diplomat was unable to confirm that such a test had taken place. North Korea is not known to carry out engine tests at Sinpo, which remains largely dedicated to ship and submarine-building."

Comments: 1 ballistic missile sub under construction. Note: SLBM ejection tests conducted during warmer, summer months.
The Diplomat, October 18, 'The Sinpo-C-Class: A New North Korean Ballistic Missile Submarine Is Under Construction
U.S. intelligence has detected a large, new submarine under construction: the Sinpo-C': https://thediplomat.com/2017/10/the-sinpo-c-class-a-new-north-korean-ballistic-missile-submarine-is-under-construction/
Clips from Diplomat article:
"North Korea has a single Gorae-class submarine in its inventory. The submarine has not entered operational use and is the only North Korean submarine capable of launching the KN11/Pukguksong-1 submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM). U.S. intelligence assesses the submarine’s submerged displacement to be approximately 2,000 tons.
The Gorae-class submarine has seen improvements as recently as this year. Early in the summer, the submarine was fitted with a new launch tube, The Diplomat has learned.
It is unknown if the launch tube is meant to accommodate the extant Pukguksong-1 SLBM or whether the Gorae-class may soon operate a newer SLBM that may require a redesigned launch tube, with the Pukguksong-1 potentially retired for a newer missile.
North Korea released potential evidence in late-August of a new solid-fuel SLBM, the Pukguksong-3, though the existence of this missile remains unconfirmed by U.S. intelligence.
A new North Korean SLBM may feature an advanced airframe using lighter composite materials that could lead to it exhibiting a considerably greater total range than the first-generation Pukguksong-1.
This summer, North Korea carried out repeated SLBM ejection tests at its test stand near the Sinpo shipyard where the Gorae-class is ported and where the Sinpo-C submarine is under construction."
U.S. intelligence recorded ejection tests on May 30, July 18, July 25, and July 30. No ejection new tests have taken place at Sinpo since July. Ejection tests allow North Korean engineers to verify the operation of the missile’s cold-launch system, which pushes the missile through the sea’s surface before its engines ignite.
Prior to North Korea’s second ICBM test in July, U.S. intelligence had assessed that a new SLBM flight test was likely. This assessment was revised downward in August following North Korea’s second ICBM test in late-July. As of early October, an SLBM flight test was not seen as imminent by U.S. intelligence.

Li'l Kim may have been warned off by the PRC, but even without that he doesn't need to do this just now, having already demonstrated that he can. (Full disclosure:  I am not he, nor have I heard from him lately--or come to think of it, ever--so I don't know his plans.)
